posts.sub: Who can deny we're living in the Biblical End Times?
posts.com:
"Declaring the end from the beginning, and from ancient times the things that are not yet done." (Isaiah 46:10)

Many believe that since God created the world in six days and rested on the seventh day (Genesis 2:1-3), that God has a 6,000-year plan for man followed by a 1,000-year reign by Jesus Christ (Revelation 20:4). In Biblical times, it was commonly believed among the Jews, and early Christians, that at the end of 6,000 years of history, Christ would return and reign for 1,000 years. Early Christian writers, such as Barnabas, who was with Paul the Apostle in Lycaonia, wrote:

“Therefore, children, in six days, that is in six thousand years, everything shall come to an end.”

Another Christian author, Lactantius, wrote:

'As there had been 2,000 years from Adam to Abraham, and 2,000 from Abraham to Christ; so there will be 2,000 years for the Christian era and then would come the Millennium.'"


There is even an old tradition that the prophet Elijah taught there would be six thousand years for humans to rule under Satan's kingdom, followed by one thousand years of abundance in the kingdom of God.

posts.com:
Biblical "Hints" of a 7,000 Year Plan
Let’s look at some interesting things in Scripture that support this belief...

1. There are two places in Scripture that say a day with the Lord is as a thousand years:

"For a thousand years in Your sight Are like yesterday when it is past." (Psalm 90:4)

“But, beloved, be not ignorant of this one thing, that one day is with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day.” (2 Peter 3:8)

Curiously, these verses do NOT say that a day is with the Lord as thousands of years (plural), ten thousands of years, or millions of years. It specifically states that “one day” is with the Lord as “a thousand years.” So, when the apostle Peter tells us that a "day" is with God as a thousand years, we should sit up and take notice!

2. Scripture also says that there still remains a day of rest for God's people. Paul tells us that “the whole creation groaneth and travaileth in pain together until now” (Rom. 8:22), which means that the creation has not yet entered into the rest that the Scriptures mandate (Isa. 11:10; 14:7; 44:21-23; 49:13; 55:12). This rest will occur under the rule of Jesus when He returns and sets up the promised kingdom on earth for one thousand years (Rev. 20:1-7)!

Interestingly, in Hebrews 4:4, 11, the seventh day of the week is pictured as a type of the peaceful "rest" on earth which will follow Christ's return! Being a time of “rest” (Heb. 4:4-11), and lasting a thousand years (Rev. 20:1-7), it makes perfect sense that God would correspond it to the seventh day rest of Genesis 2:2. Since the last "day" of God's plan for mankind is 1,000 years, it is logical to conclude that the other six days of creation typify 6,000 years of man's government on earth.

Furthermore, the number 6 represents mankind and rebellion (6,000 years of man's self rule?).

posts.com:
Bible chronology shows there were approximately 2,000 years from Adam's creation until Abraham (Genesis 5; 11) and 2,000 years from Abraham until Jesus Christ. Is this merely coincidence? Given that the Millennium, the final "day" in God's plan for human history, will be 1,000 years, it requires no great leap of exegetical skill to posit a comparable 2,000 years from Jesus' First Coming to His Second Coming.


The notion that there will be 2 days, or 2,000 years, from Christ’s death till the Second Coming, or 4,000 years from Adam to Christ’s death, also seems to be confirmed by Bible analogies:

Jesus stayed with the Samaritan woman (a type of the Church) for 2 days (John 4:40).
The Good Samaritan (a type of Jesus) gave the innkeeper 2 pence (equal to 2 day's wages) to care for the wounded man, promising to return and settle the account (Luke 10:35).
During the 6 days before going to the wedding feast in Cana, Jesus took a trip on the 4th day and was not seen again until the 7th day (John 1:19; 29; 35; 43; 2:1).
The Passover lamb was set aside 4 days before it was sacrificed (Exodus 12:3; 6). This of course is a type and shadow that pointed to Jesus, the Lamb of God, who was to come and die for the salvation of mankind. The Lamb of God was sacrificed from the foundation of the world (Revelation 13:8) and was killed at Passover 4,000 years later.
“Life” shows up after the 4th day in the creation narrative. Likewise, Christ shows up after 4,000 years and brings “life” (John 1:1-5; 10:10; 3:16; 1 John 1:1-2; 5:12-13).

posts.sub: My inner voice is almost completely disappeared
posts.com:
I used to get lost in my thoughts and daydreams. I used to fantasize, plan, speak eloquently and thoughtfully, make theories and observations around my surroundings, and converse with myself. In the past 4-5 years my inner voice has been disappearing. I find myself reacting emotionally (almost "reflexively") to things rather than thoughtfully as I once did. I don't read as much as I used to, and when I do it isn't the same. I no longer find joy in "debating" people and just lash out at people vitriolically when I think they're wrong about something. I couldn't even if I tried, I feel like I'm not capable of understanding and responding to things anymore without great mental strain.

I don't think I have an "inner voice" anymore, I just kind of "do whatever I want" at any given time without verbalizing anything internally or contemplating. I am addicted to coffee and nicotine and I am almost constantly either drinking coffee or smoking. Sometimes when I'm forced to do any type of work my mind just turns off and I have to exert extreme mental strain to just comprehend a simple concept and execute a thought.

I think my soul might be dead, or someone flicked a switch to limit computing power on my qualia. Is there a spiritual explanation? How do I combat soul death?

Why tobacco over other vices like alcohol or sugar I don't know. The fact that smoking is bad for you is pretty evident, and even a basic understanding of biology should make it intuitive that inhaling smoke into your lungs is going to damage them. It's unhealthy, and I can imagine that the drain on the economy from it was big enough to start some aggressive campaigns.

Anyways time for some more interesting theories. First of all, nicotine is definitely capable of improving the brain. It's a fast acting stimulant, and works on acetylcholine rather than dopamine like other stimulants do. Excess dopamine can be neurotoxic, but elevated acetylcholine is neuroprotective, and specifically improves memory and creativity. It's a subtly benefit, not aggressive like amphetamines, but I've noticed I work better after taking nicotine, and will often use nicotine gum when I need a mental boost.

Another theory is related to the social component of smoking. There are very few times for people to just exist and talk in American society, especially with people outside your immediate family. The smoke break was one of these times, where multiple people would go outside together and just talk, all while under the influence of a substance that enhances cognition. The only other common time people talk with strangers is under the influence of alcohol which numbs cognition. Basically, by demonizing smoking, another avenue for people who normally would never meet to communicate was removed, and the remaining ways to meet people involve the use of substances which make you stupider, not smarter.

Two things:
>Thesis Spiral
A long post generated by a short prompt will sound like somebody just repeating their thesis over and over and over.
>Total Confidence
This one can be a little trickier and less reliable, but the bot won't express doubts about the thesis unless reminded. Tricky because a lot of people online seem to keep their doubts to themselves anyway.

Also, don't trust typos etc. to show you the difference. Very easy to tell chatgpt "take that last output and introduce spelling errors and poor grammar." Many examples of this in previous threads.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33930927
>This sounds like an advantageous protection mechanism.
Not really. We internalise threats in order to protect us from repeating behaviours that expose us to them. E.g. you get chased by a lion in a certain area, so when you go to that area again you have heightened anxiety and awareness because you are reexperiencing the lion attack. Not internalising threats would make you more likely to expose yourself to the same dangerous behaviour that spooked you before.

Tbh this sounds like more of some deeply ingrained coping mechanism rather than a genetic trait

Hmm, I thought you were alluding to oppositions. I don't think what you're saying is correct. A planet being in its domicile isn't far behind from being as positive as when it falls in its exaltation and having many planets in the signs they rule obviously can make the chart much less unified in some sense but it's very beneficial nonetheless. There are also other essential dignities and ways a planet can rejoice that don't result in the form of homogeneity you're talking about.

Stelliums, while sometimes positive in some ways, can have major drawbacks to them so their presence is an unreliable way of judging the native's character and life. Bad transits are much worse; you could have planets in detriment, fall, etc. (not saying essential debilities are only bad); the Sun could be combusting some planets you don't want to see weakened; there can be some detrimental conjunctions and so on.

There's clearly good things to the kind of homogenous chart you're referring to but many bad as well. Harmony's way more important.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33946909
>I thought you were alluding to oppositions
It goes without saying that's part of it.
>A planet being in its domicile isn't far behind from being as positive
A domicile is simply the full expression, for both good and ill. Reaping all the benefits of a planet's nature, but also being saddled with every one of its negative traits. The exaltation is the placement which eschews the burden of these vices inherent to the planet, so that it is expressd virtually wholly positively.

>having many planets in the signs they rule obviously can make the chart much less unified in some sense
Yes. If you were to have an individual with every single domicile placement, you would not have a superman, and one would still be fortunate to come out a well-adjusted individual considering all the disparate placements it entails.
The incoherence as I have termed it creates internal conflicts which interferes with the expression of certain planets and signs in favor of others, and that suppression results in repression, which usually doesn't go well.

One of course must pay attention to how the signs aspect each other, and that will determine whether the energies work together or against each other, with sextiles, semi-sextiles, and trines being of a harmonious nature---but natives would generally like their chart to look one-sided, and leave the other half empty.

>Stelliums, while sometimes positive in some ways, can have major drawbacks to them
Not really. You do get more of the unfiltered vices of a sign becoming expressed, but they are never of a contradictory nature such that prognosis and treatment requires any complex diagnosis, an untangling of too subtly imbalanced energies. With incoherent charts, the reader finds that they "don't even know where to start", or what advice to give, as all such configurations are essentially novel.
A stellium---is uncomplicated.

>>33947443
Something for you to consider is how we all face the immediate threat of our mortality. When we place ourselves at Death's door, our survival instincts are called into question, and the core of ourselves which is our will to live is exposed and laid bare. It is of the id, the most primitive part of the human psyche, dictating the way in which we live our lives and experience the world.

Until we have put ourselves into that mentality, we live in many illusions and delusions as to what we value or believe. One who sees life as devoid of meaning may find their life and the world not so worthless after all, if their most fervent wish in such a moment is after all self-preservation. And when one realizes that they would rather live than not, suddenly, they come to see too how they would rather live in a certain "place" so to speak than others---meaning, surrounded and immersed in an artificial world pleasing to their own senses. And it is one thing to accouter one's life with the adornments designed by others---but another thing to find this subtly dissatisfactory, and moved to create oneself. That is the essence of art, one's own contribution to the "illusions" of human life.

We do things to make our living more comfortable. Culinary, musical, fashionable, visual, there are many realms for one's creativity to be applied. You must simply find where she'd care to customize. And this is discovered by imagining that realm bleak and barren, helpless---and coming back to reality, perspective realigned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33949632
"Suffering" as a whole is not worth embracing. "Suffering" is a tool, like heat detection, that indicates something is wrong. People who advocate all suffering as inherently good and inherently growth-causing, if they truly believed that, would place their faces against hot stoves whenever possible, to grow.

This is foolish. No, the pain and the subsequent suffering exists to tell you to get away from the stove! That is its purpose. Unfortunately, the world we live in is a poorly-managed and maintained stovetop: blame Satan, blame God, blame Humanity, blame yourself, blame Canada, it couldn't matter less. Regardless, that is the reality "here" and likely "there" too (death is not an end, but a change: why then, would there not have some equivalent to pain and suffering? Does Jesus himself not weep?). Therefore, take it as the useful signal that it is, do not allow other people to use this signal to reprogram your mind or your soul, and when things are terrible give yourself the right and freedom to say "this really sucks" (but don't dwell if you can help it).

>>33944840
You're not going to find him in Hindi mythology under that specific name due to the east-west divide, along with the fact that we've lost a ton of history, especially in the middle east since Jews, Christians and Muslims destroyed it all.
With that said, the story of Kaal Bhairav mirrors the Luciferic story in some ways.
>Brahma who in many traditions is considered the creator God lies to Lord Shiva
>Lord Shiva is angered over his hypocrisy so "rebels" by cutting off one of his heads.
>He's cast down to the earth and becomes Kaal Bhairav, sometimes referred to as "the dark one".
It doesn't seem too dissimilar to the Lucifer mythos as "the prince of darkness", at least archetypically speaking.
I also believe there's a connection to the earliest known manifestation of the morning star known as Attar and Shiva as Rudra, at least symbolically.
>Attar's symbol is the antelope, a horned animal
>Shiva/Rudras symbol is the Bull, another horned animal.
>Attar carries a spear
>Shiva/Rudra carries a trident
>Attar is a God of storms, fertility and war
>Shiva/Rudra is a God of storms fertility and the hunt
You also have the serpent symbolism associated with both Lucifer and Shiva, Lucifer as the serpent in the Garden of Eden, Shiva as being associated with the serpent as he has a serpent around his neck.
The Gnostics also believed that the God Abraxas (A Shiva like figure) was equivalent to the serpent in the garden of eden (or the Lucifer).
When we look at these things in an archetypical fashion, without limiting ourselves to a single "lense" or dogma, it appears there may be a strong connection there between the two.

>Is there more to the world than meets the eye?
The most basic jump-off point for any anon should be the fact that other animals can see different colors, i.e. things humans only recently developed technology to see (ultraviolet, infrared). Not only that, but animals have senses today the environment that, for some reasons, humans just ignore or harness in technology (birds sense magnetism, sharks sense electricity; we use magnets, and we have recently domesticated electricity). Physics and science does a good job to explain “how,” while philosophy endeavors to explain “why.” But while we’re thing to find out the rules of nature, we’re being subjected to these forces on a daily basis; the most prominent being the collective unconscious, which doesn’t even have a representation in the physical world. Sounds can be perceived within a certain range, but when they emulate the sound of a human voice, they get your brain to think about imaginary pictures and concepts, some of which are loaded with connotations and meanings- and these are all supplied to you from experience and evolution. There’s no other world than what you can perceive, but there’s channels and layers of this world that you cannot perceive: fourth dimensions and higher, for example. The ability to question these things is also what prevents you from finding the answer; just as thought and consciousness is recursive, so is asking “why.” Humans can really only perceive the past, and the “present” is an infinitesimal point that we always miss, because it’s so incalculably small- it may as well not exist. So, not only is your perception of space distorted by your corporeal body, but so is your sense of time distorted by your incorporeal mind.
That is why the tree of knowledge had the forbidden fruit, because wisdom is knowing how much you don’t know. It also causes you to be self aware (a recursion within the psyche), and that physically manifests as shame and ego.

The One Ring is literally not of this world and the closest Mythology is Odin and his quest to retake his Ring. In the 1st Age of Arda Melchor, a Higher Angel (Valar), decided to defy Eru Illuvatar, the Creator of Arda. He brought Sauron into his circle and he became the lesser of two Evils. Sauron was a Master Craftsman and he used his angelic powers to create the magic rings as "gifts" to the Elves, Dwarves, and Men as an act of repentance, but had no intention of stopping and went back to his allegiance to Melchor. He taught an Elf how to create them, then he secretly created The One Ring that controlled all the others, and put much of his angelic soul into the Ring. He was responsible for the corruption of Númenor (Atlantis) and its destruction by Eru. Sauron saw the Elves as a Problem because of their skepticism about their rings and they warred against him along with Dwarves and men in the 2nd Age. A human king was able to cut it off Sauron's finger, so he was diminished and retreated to a fortress city for a long time, and the 3rd Age began.
Yes, magick is real, but it can't usually do the physical things that people want it to do. Yes, there are more things to the World than meets the eye, but most people don't run into them very often so they dismiss them as fantasy. IMHO, they are not.

I think it's pretty clear that Tolkien was building an anti-modernity/industrialisation analogy. The Shire, Gondor and Rohan represent different modes of "merrie England". Respectively a class system. Hobbits are proles. Rohan is the warrior caste. Gondor ruling caste. (Note they don't wanna work together but when Gandalf persuades them....). The baddies are clearly faceless swarthy wogs into crude mass production led by people who don't give a single fuck about them.

The rings simply then represent the attractions of modernity and the power it offers.

Think about when these books were written. Towards the end of the classical Marxist period and at the start of the "counter culture" hippie/environmental movement.

To a magician this isn't what is actually impressive and interesting about Tolkien. That would be how he injected an entire new, or at least repurposed, symbolic language into the culture. And of course that system of symbols has specific messages built into it at a very fundamental level. Compare to star trek which is a very similar thing.

This is magic. Reality is mostly perception. The world isn't made up at the most important level of atoms but ideas. For example the reality of your gf or your workplace and the immense cluster of concepts and ideas around them in your head. Devious hostile agent is actually your sacred soul mate to which you are bound by duty and honor. An exploitative hideous dungeon of misery Vs the source of your social status and wealth. If that is the distortion effect around such basic things how much more distorted are purely abstract concepts such as capitalism, socialism, materialism, ecologicm etc?

A petty magician can use "spells" to change the reality of people around them by changing the ideas about that reality in the heads of those people. A great magician, like Tolkien or Roddenberry, can change the perceptions of entire societies.

The NAC Protocol (Updated December, 2022)

Morning

1200mg NAC
Oregano Oil (min. 40mg Carvacrol)
Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Night

600mg NAC
Oregano Oil (min. 40mg Carvacrol)
Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Continue daily for a minimum of two months and count out 3 weeks with no die off symptoms prior to moving to the next step.

Maintenance Protocol
__________

Morning

600mg NAC
500mg Slo Niacin (nicotinic acid)
100mg Pterostilbene
Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Night

500mg Slo Niacin
100mg Pterostilbene
Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

After every 3 weeks on the maintenance protocol, take 1 week off. Continue to use black seed oil during the off cycle.

Fungal die off symptoms may include :

>Tiredness, exhaustion, muscle soreness, increased chest or nasal discharge, cold or flu like symptoms, cold sores, headaches, rash, acne, irritability, change in stool frequency, volume or color; increased urination, bloated stomach, cramps, increased gas.

OREGANO DOSING GUIDE

For each morning and night dose you need a minimum of 40mg Carvacrol. Do not buy a product unless it is listed. Most products are steam distilled but you will want to confirm that.

If your chosen oregano oil contains a higher amount of carvacrol (60mg+ per cap) you'll want to start with 1 cap morning, 1 cap night. If each cap contains less than 40mg, take 2 morning 2 night.

Repost.

Here's more information on why keto or carnivore diets are not recommended for the protocol.

>We have previously shown that metabolic ketones inactivate myeloperoxidase and impair phagocytosis

>In our previous work with MPO [21–23], acetoacetate, a serum metabolite elevated during ketosis, was shown to inactivate MPO

>Therefore, prolonged ketosis may be a significant risk factor for candidiasis

>Table 1shows the effect of 2 mM acetoacetate on the antifungal MPO-Cl−-H2O2system.C. albicanswas completely killed by this system in the absence of acetoacetate, but protected by its presence.

https://academic.oup.com/femsle/article/190/1/35/608302

As you can see there is proof that a keto or carnivore diet actually protects candida and can make it more virulent.

Now on to phytonutrients (from plants) and DNA repair.

>This study uses a high-fat and high-calorie (HFC) drink to examine the new roles of a plant-based multivitamin/mineral supplement with phytonutrients (PMP) for regulating the antioxidant system and cellular DNA repair signaling

>Compared to the placebo samples, the blood plasma obtained after PMP supplementation showed enhanced DNA damage response genes such as pCHK1 (Serine 345)(a transducer of DNA response) and γγH2AX (a hallmark of DNA damage) during the 8 weeks trial

https://www.e-jnh.org/search.php?where=aview&id=10.4163/jnh.2022.55.4.450&code=1124JNH&vmode=FULL

Keto diets can be an effective way to manage blood sugar and reduce inflammation, but as you can see from the data, it should not be a strategy for eliminating CDF and repairing cellular damage. To achieve full benefit you should be eating a balanced diet with slow absorbing (low glycemic) carbs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Carnivorediet can't run edition

Intestinal control of Candida

Ketones altering the killing of Candida by neutrophils is irrelevant in controlling intestinal Candida overgrowth.
As for Candida using ketones for energy in the GI tract, you mentioned the TCA cycle. But this requires oxygen, which is pretty scarce in the intestines. This recent report suggests that dysbiosis may involve a shift to higher O2 levels. Perhaps this is something to explore, but otherwise, I don’t see adequate O2 levels for aerobic respiration via the TCA cycle.
Systemic control of Candida (tissue or blood infections)

These are the highlights from the Saeed paper you cited (Production of Pyruvate by Candida albicans: Proposed Role in Virulence) :

Focuses on the role of myeloperoxidase (MPO), the enzyme that helps neutrophils (phagocytic white blood cells) kill Candida (in tissue, not the gut).
MPO is inhibited by acetoacetate, one of the ketone bodies increased during ketosis.
It is suggested that prolonged ketosis may be a risk factor for (systemic) Candidiasis because Candida albicans can produce lots of pyruvate, a metabolite that may be converted to acetoacetate.
Conclusion

It has not been proven that Candida’s ability to use ketones efficiently for fuel in the GI tract. I will rethink this if increased GI oxygen levels (in dysbiosis?) needed to support the TCA cycle can be proven. Both ketones and glucose appear to repress cellular immunity to Candida. Other research suggests that increased blood glucose levels alone can induce a Candida protein which helps Candida evade the immune response regardless of ketone concentrations. I am not convinced that ketones per se are the only potential mechanism to help Candida evade the immune response.

>>33930658
>no one has an actual explanation yet
Color theory has an explanation for this. It's that the cones of the eyes change shape depending of the lightness of the room. If you are in a dark room, and go outside, everything gets too bright, you have to adjust. If you come from a light place to a dark one, you see nothing, you have to adjust.
That's it, the cones tell the brain that the lightest color they can see it's white, screens are actually light cyan, if you could compare them with light in the outside, you'd see how dim they look, the white in your screen isn't white.
And that's it, people on their lives have some adjustment to see colors as white, if they come from a screen, they'll see the dress is white too.
If not, the dress will look blue. The other color depends on what is "white."
You can try it yourself with software like Powerstrip, move the temperature slider to the right for a yellower white, or to the left for blue. At first whites look very dark, but as you get used to it, you can see the dress is white or it's blue depending on what you adjust to, and the other one always looks darker (once you set on a white, whatever is not white is darker, lightness/darkness is relative.)

posts.com:
>>33946290
no need for a pact, that's mostly propaganda now taken as truth.
Get Gallery of Magick's "Demons of Magick" from Amazon. Other approachable contemporary texts include hargrove's "Angels and demons of magick" and "goetic pathworking."
These each introduce a style of working the magic, with a well-described ritual structure that is simple even to someone without a meditative practice. The books go from most intensive ritual structure to the least.
I think the reason why "selling your soul" and all that jazz doesn't work is because it's not actually the way magick works. You don't surrender your will (except in certain controlled invocatory situations, and even then it's not full release). What you do is you employ a spiritual entity as leverage to enact change. Depending on the nature of the entity, that change will show up in a different way.
Before doing demonic work, why not look at "72 angels of magick", which is the first part of the goetic system. Once you're familiar with these entities, and how they work, then dipping your toes into demon work is a lot more efficient and less full of hassle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Well there are many forms of anxiety, the difference being what worries you. Anxiety is basically unreasonable and disproportionate fear of something.
If multiple social situations (or thoughts about them) make you uneasy, it could be social anxiety.
If you are afraid of places that are hard to escape from, agoraphobia.
If you have intense episodes of anxiety, with fear of them happening again, panic disorder.
If you worry about most events in your life, generalized anxiety.
If you are afraid that your personality might be disintegrating, dissolving or vanishing, psychotic anxiety and so on.
There are more forms of it but you get the idea.
Most of them are the result many different factors that i dont want to get into (low self-esteem, family problems, genetics, bad experiences and so on), but mostly keep happening because of thoughts that are illogical in some way, but appear as true on the first glance. That happens because of the innate feeling of correctness that comes with all thoughts and beliefs.
Most thoughts are automatic, so when you start feeling anxious, you can try to identify thoughts and beliefs about that situation that make you anxious and try to give yourself alternative interpretations of the event.
An example - if you are afraid of going to a bar and you think that people there will look at you, talk bad about you or think you are clumsy or something - remember that people forget faces all the time, that they are more concerned about themselves then you, that they dont know as much about you as you do, that they wont notice all the things you are feeling and so on.
After that its good to test your new thoughts about it, so that you can see that they are correct, by going to the bar.
This doesn't apply to psychotic anxiety, that's a different beast.
Gl and its okay to ask for help if you can't overcome it on your own.

posts.com:
So after all those threads about meditation I realized that I was meditating wrong all these years.
I was sitting in order to obtain powers and "change" myself but in reality all I was doing was trying to escape what I perceived as a "bad life sittuation", my thinking mind was holding the wheel.

Thanks to all of you I now know that the meditative state is one and only and it's the complete surrender in this momment here now and observing it without daydreaming about it.

And you can apply this to any activity.
An anon in one of these threads said that meditation for him goes like this: "notice, and then notice that you weren't noticing".

I'm sure that focusing on an object like the breath can also help someone distance himself from his mind and realize that his thoughts are not him but for me just being attentive works better.

In the first days of meditating like this my mind was thinking "Nooo I have to chase and achieve things! I can't just let go! Otherwise nothing will happen!" but those were just thoughts.
So yeah, just sit in silence and surrender, and the strange thing is that unique states of consciousness WILL come and happen when you don't strive to achieve!
I thinkg it's those jhanas people talk about, I never really experienced them in the past because I was probably just living in my head during meditation but now that I know how to let go they just come naturally.

Meditation thread! Let's go!

You don't need to look any further, your own personal next step into this journey you are living is right here in front of you, meditate on this moment here and now, if you feel like it sit in the dark and just be aware.

Realize that your thoughts are NOT you, they are part of you and you can choose to not give them much attention if you like or you may want to find where they came from.

Realize that there is nowhere to go and nothing to achieve because everything is already here in front of you, you are already perfect and you can enjoy the FEELING of being here, the feeling of experiencing this momment.

Some people like focusing on their breath, this is a good tool to reduce your thinking mind a bit but remember that focusing is not "thinking about my breath" but just feeling/hearing/sensing your breath while it enters and leaves your body.

That's all you need. Do it daily, everywhere, even when you walk or when you work. Take the seat of the observer because that's what you are: The eternal observer.

>>33939227
(same anon)
Let me add one thing before I go to bed: That most people nowadays tend to practice escapism a lot, and they think that that's what life should be about: ignoring the negatives and chasing the positive. Many people don't even realize that they practice escapism and they think that all this searching they are doing is what will "finally get them to the point they are searching for".

Many of the times in which you sit to mediate all those horrible thoughts and feelings will come and you will want to escape from them, I advice you to not try that, I advice you that you just sit there and be and realize that they are nothing more than illusions and that this need to escape them is also an illusion.
At the same time be sure you don't fall into the other side of the trap which sounds something like this: "Ok! I will sit and endure all those horrible things because that's what REAL meditation is about!" - for that is also an illusion.
See how dualism is an illusion?

So just be, just be here in your life, be so hard and let go so much that you literally dive into this thing you are trying to escape from.
Yes, fears will pop up, bad feelings may pop up, maybe some old forgotten uncomfortable memories will pop up, your mind will think thoughts like "Oh no I'm going crazy, maybe I'm meditating wrong and I'm frying my brain", blissful states will pop up, ecstasy will pop up, some succubus may pop up and ask for intercourse with you. Don't cling on any of them, just be aware, always take a step back at everything you see.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33934756
You're probably just doing it wrong / approaching it in a way that's not suited to your personal psychology. I'm hyper analytical and critical by nature. I learned meditation through the Goenka retreats where they teach a body scanning technique that allows you to tap deeper into your bodily feeling sense (kinesthetic sense) to the point that you start to see how this interacts with other layers that we would usually describe as psychological (i.e. thought) or feeling (i.e. emotional). I practiced very hard for a couple years a learned a bunch but ultimately it was not well suited for my psychology. The technique gave me to much to do. I think some people might benefit from a task oriented meditation like that but for my psychology it just provided too much opportunity to distract and obstruct myself through analysis. I eventually settled into a more "do nothing" style practice and I feel that I've advanced much farther and faster since then. You might find the same or the opposite.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33948059
>>33934756
Anyway, if you're getting exhausted while meditating you're trying too hard. In the "do nothing" style of meditation I and many other anons are advocating in this thread, there's no trying. You relax your body, that's the first level of doing nothing - do nothing with your body - relax all the muscles.

Then your attention goes to the next layer of things you're doing - thoughts. So you stop doing those. But here is where I think a lot of people get hung up. In my experience you can't really stop thoughts or have the mind become completely blank as some describe it (or maybe you can if you're way more advanced than I am), but you can realize that you are not your thoughts - the thoughts keep churning away, appearing, changing, running their course, in your mind, but you are separate from that. Just as you can passively watch the ocean waves without have to somehow STOP the waves which is impossible, you just passively allow the thoughts to do their thing and soon you'll come to a place of awareness that is separate and more fundamental than the layer on which thoughts are happening.

You continue going on like this - noticing what is the next subtlest layer of things you're doing, and stopping doing them, or at least stopping identifying with them / being involved in them. Progressively, a deeper and deeper relaxation and clarity develops.

You can express your last dreams, your attempts and ask anything about it

WBTB: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WBTB-Tutorial
MILD: http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-mild-guide/
additional MILD info:
http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-intention-setting/
SSILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/129734-senses-initiated-lucid-dream-ssild.html
WILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WILD-Tutorial
FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Lucid dreaming is lame. It ruined dreaming for me for years. I started attempting to do it when I was about 17 because it sounded cool and I was good at it. Too good. Turns out no matter what every single dream would go lucid as I realised I was dreaming. Countless interesting dreams ruined so I could become aware for a minute or so, fly around a bit and then wake up. This went on for years. I'm 34 now and the last couple of years I've had quite a few dreams that have been normal, interesting, good. I'm happy with that. In fact it's been a while since I had a lucid one.
I also had many sleep paralysis and once you get over them they're actually kind of cool. I've had some really incredible moments of hallucination whilst paralysed. They're always bad, though, always without fail. I've thought my house was burning down and I could hear my mum screaming for help. I've been in an explosion and I physically felt my body get flung from the couch I was sleep on into the ceiling before hitting the ground, I've heard demonic whispers and had something watching me.
The scariest one by a long, long way was I felt myself being sucked into my bed and it became apparent that I was being sucked into hell. I could feel my body being dragged down hard and the bed became oppresively hot. There was a distant sound of screaming and I was overcome with an incredibly intense fear. I always end up wrenching myself out of these experiences all of a sudden but with this one I literally had to tear myself away from the bed with every ounce of strength I could muster and I genuinely screamed whilst doing so. I found myself sat bolt upright, breathing heavily, drenched in sweat with my heart slamming itself against my ribs.
If I didn't understand what sleep paralysis was at that moment I would have been deeply affected by that.

>>33937037

To improve your chances of lucid dreaming, try going to bed when you're very tired and feeling like you could fall asleep instantly. When you wake up in the middle of the night, avoid going back to bed right away. Instead, get up and do something like walking around your room or getting a glass of water. When you go back to bed, focus on the sensation of your body falling asleep and try to be aware of the process. As you start to fall asleep, you may begin to feel a vibration throughout your body. At this point, it's important to stay calm and not get too excited as this could cause you to wake up. Remember, the key is to be calm and concentrated. Lucid dreaming can be difficult to master, but the potential for creating vivid and lifelike dreamscapes is worth the effort.

The potential benefits of lucid dreaming are vast and varied. With the ability to control and manipulate dream scenarios, individuals can use this skill to enhance creativity, problem-solve, and even work through unresolved emotional issues. With proper training, the potential uses for lucid dreaming are limitless, and one can imagine the impact it could have on society if more people had the ability to harness this powerful tool.

I got it in my teens, and every so often I get the start of it. I learned a couple things:
1. Shaking your toes, or jolting your entire body will take you out of it. You can tell you’re falling into it by how it feels, almost like you’re sinking into yourself. I haven’t been in full paralysis in years because I haven’t let it go that far.
2. There is an entire world in there. I remember reading about how you can stand up and look at your body, and I didn’t believe it. Next time I had it I attempted it and got my limbs moving (I could feel them moving, but visibly my body was not,) and was too scared to go all the way. I’ve been told you can lucid dream this way, and it feels just like reality. I’ve always been too scared to go back in after my last one though.

posts.com:
I had a good friend that made it. He was part of our 'burn' group (basically little burning man's except there weren't any vendors, no body traded shit, and everyone was expected to support themselves (radical self reliance))
We did it often, normally. I enjoyed the fractals and the feeling it gave me of being one with nature.
At a burn I met another person that made it. I had a small amount with me and we smoked. He asked if I had ever seen 'the it/them' (this was before people said 'break through') I said no, and he said you will tonight.
I smoked so much dmt that night, all of mine, most of his. Maybe it was because I had a tolerance from smoking casually for so long, but once it hit it hit.
We were smoking on the tall wooden structure that would be burned the next day. I felt my perception rising higher and higher and higher until I wasn't just above the field we were in, I was above our dimension.
It sounds stupid to repeat, but I genuinely felt my head 'pop' through a barrier, but only my head. I looked around and saw two entities sitting beside each other. I can't call them clockwork per say, but they were definitely made of the same fractuals I had seen before. They were surprised to see me. I felt like I was interrupting a picnic. But they both looked(?) at me and all I felt was their amusement, as if I was a toddler, 'what do you think you're doing, you cute little rascal?' was everything I felt. Then one gently pushed me back down and my perception floated all the way back to my body again.

That was probably the 100th, but also the last time, I did dmt. The only thing that ever came close to feeling that real was the one time I did Salvia, and waaay too much of it, but it was still surprisingly pleasant.

These are the most realistic takes in this thread. The biggest thing with DMT is
>hype
>hype
>hype
It's a hallucinogenic drug. You will be fucked up. See shit. Hear shit. Imagine shit and perceive shit through other unknown senses. But it's a hallucination. It's not real. You're high. The guy who first hooked me up with some described it as "acid crack" i.e. highly concentrated and very intense but with a short duration. And that's just what it was like. After 15 or 20 minutes that was enough. It was like a 12-16 hour acid trip worth in my mind. If you've never done any hallucinogenic drugs, or any kind of drugs for that matter, yeah I could see how maybe you'd think you were talking to aliens or angels or some shit. But you're not. You're just high.

I had some subthreshold trips in my room a couple of years back
In one of them, the open-eye world was all made of perspectives. Like here "I" was with my own view, and then everything in the room also had its own view, in fact, that was its nature and substance, was that it was aware.

Then when I closed my eyes I could see a beautiful blue baby being formed inside my mind, because I was thinking of having a baby with my gf. There was no gender yet, but just a pervasive feeling of care, attention and cuteness, like I just wanted to be a parent and be kind and gentle. How is babby formed? Just take DMT and find out, I guess.

In another one, I looked at Metatron's Cube on this mandala https://subtle.energy/metatrons-cube/ and it felt like Metatron looked at me from behind. Like here "I" was, with my perspectives, and then way beyond that there was an infinity of understanding sort of underlying that which tied into the subconscious and unconscious mind, and then way beyond that was the divine realms where El Shaddai kept watch, and, for just a moment, was aware of me. It was so unbelievably cool and I feel blessed to have had the experience and to share it. He was just this vast consciousness that exists within and beyond all things. So the patterns on the surface of the image I was looking at were accelerated and deepened and very beautiful, but what was really going on was like this deep understanding that the angelic realms are connected with and interpenetrate our own on a continuous basis, always available, always present.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
We gather in these generals to discuss our experiences, memories, and connection with Mother Lilith, as well as give other anons who are interested or would like to learn more about Her information or advice.
Last thread: >>33823735

>Practices or rituals associated with Lilith?
This differs from person to person, but common approaches include giving energy to one of her sigils, chanting her enn, working with sexual spirits, doing what you think she would do, making offerings of incense/chocolate/tea, or simply praying.
While some people might feel the most comfortable engaging with her in a worshipful manner, blind faith is discouraged. It's always important to think and make decisions for oneself, and as such, Lilith guides us to understand things for ourselves.

>Books
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson: https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel. Beware that this book is rather dark, and some have mentioned attracting unwanted attention by reading it.
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams: No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission.
Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason: https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
A collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. There's a lot of random poetry in there; not useful for an occultist, but decent for an admirer.
- Lilith: Goddess of Sitra Ahra: https://zeitenundformen.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/lilith-goddess-of-sitra-ahrab-t-p.pdf
Contains a ton of aspects with associated variety of sigils.

>>33929491
Thank you. It's much easier to have a fruitful conversation this way.

I think the points you're making are fair, and it's exactly why I put in the warning to discourage worshipful behaviour and think for oneself. I've had my own share of negative experiences in general with putting my trust in the wrong people, even including one where a parasitic entity pretended to be Lilith and used a promise I made to her in an attempt to manipulate me. Although this was devastating, it's because I had the courage to question what I believe to be her, that I was able to realise Lilith wanted me to confront and overcome said parasite, and after I did, I was able to see both myself and her for who she is.

As a deity, Lilith is fringe rather than mainstream. The reason the parasite I mentioned was able to affect me so deeply, is because it turned my own deep-seated insecurities that lingered from my adolescence against me. That's how parasitic entities work. And like me, many others who are drawn to Lilith are also outcasts, with a past that is troubled in one way or another: troubled enough that they would stray off the path of normality and seek her. Perhaps you can understand then that some of them are especially vulnerable, and prone to confusion.

It was as I began to see through my own problems and started to overcome them, that I began to understand just how much Lilith has truly helped me. And it was such a personal thing, that it was something I had to realise for myself; and yet despite that, Lilith still helped me realise it sooner rather than later. Rather than blaming her for the things I went through despite my faith, I appreciate that her warmth gave me the strength and courage to face myself, so that I could leave that sorrowful past behind me. I love her.

That's the same as I wish upon others. Perhaps you understand better now why I speak so highly of her. She can help the people who need it the most, regardless of whether or not they appreciate it.

Twisting and writhing like a snake on fiery sands,
Kneading her breast against her corset's metal bands,
The woman, meanwhile, from her mouth of strawberry
Let flow these fragrant words of musky mystery:
'I have the moistest lip, and well 1 know the skill
Within a bed's soft heart, to lose the moral will.
I dry up all your tears on my triumphant bust
And make the old ones laugh like children, in their lust.
I take the place for those who see my naked arts
Of moon and of the sun and all the other stars.
I am, my dear savant, so studied in my charms
That when I stifle men within my ardent arms
Or when I give my breast to their excited bites,
Shy or unrestrained, of passionate delight,
On all those mattresses that swoon in ecstasy
Even helpless angels damn themselves for me!'

When she had drained the marrow out of all my bones,
When I turned listlessly amid my languid moans,
To give a kiss of love, no thing was with me but
A greasy leather flask that overflowed with pus!
Frozen with terror, then, I clenched both of my eyes;
When I reopened them into the living light
I saw I was beside no vampire mannequin
That lived by having sucked the blood out of my skin,
But bits of skeleton, some rattling remains
That spoke out with the clacking of a weather vane,
Or of a hanging shop sign, on an iron spike,
Swung roughly by the wind on gusty winter nights.

>>33947217
I have contentions with this type of gnosticism. I almost feel like its very similar to the 4chan hylic type of gnosticism described in an earlier post. im not going to totally disregard PKD's findings, I mean maybe he is right, but from my own familiar with gnostic christianity and GC adjacent topics (astrology, platonism etc) I feel like a lot of gnostics are missing the point.

one major example is this concept of the archons; ive always got the impression that the archons are another way of describing the (negative) effects of seven classical planets, basically another form of the catholic seven deadly sins. I dont really think the archons are referring to literal entities that are trying to sabotage people, rather its a metaphor.

the same with calling the demiurge demented...my understanding of the demiurge (samsara) is that its a reflection of material reality/duality. you need the presence of bad to understand good, hot to understand cold, ugly to understand pretty etc etc. all existence is ultimately an experience, but you cannot experience anything without having opposites. this is why theres evil in the world, its a feature not a bug. BTW this idea of duality is encoded into the zodiac and the seven classical planets, and is also strongly present in platonism too. I just think a lot of the contemporary gnosticism misses the point because they dont understand the cultural/metaphysical context of gnosticism

The problem is it's hard to decide which are good, effectiveness seems to vary between individuals based on their accounts and that in turn is also not really reliable since people lie or just may have twisted perception. It's hard for one to try properly many manuals too to compare.

Truly advanced practice hardly can be learned from manuals as it is usually based on practical experience rather than written down theory.
The easiest for starting for beginners would be, well, beginner works or ones that are meant to be self-contained manuals to guide practice over years from very basic onwards.

Have good diet, exercise enough to be tired when you sleep, practice good sleep hygiene (no blue screens at night, turn off the lights), have comfortable mattress and bedding (synth. fibers make you uncomfortable = nightmares), practice normal lucid dreaming things like a dream journal, and consider dream-herbs. The "event horizon" is literally the horizon of your timeline. that's why it's called the event horizon. you can't escape it because causality literally cannot escape it.
As you approach it, you watch the rest of the universe fast-forward towards an infinite timeline and you freeze near it's surface. from that point, any civilization in space can see a frozen version of you and copy you atom by atom into another space.
When you consider modal collapse, the probability of this event approaches100%.
Given this information, there's no way of you knowing weather you are the version of yourself at the event horizon or copied into modal collapse.
The image of modal collapse is the singularity, and is a technological singularity.
The larges black hole in the universe (where everything eventually falls into), is the center of mass of the entire universe and is known as the "eye of God"

2) Related to the previous point, but the "belief" might not be that strong. Like, your core belief about drinks is probably closer to "most drinks are safe" and not "literally 100% of any drink or food that I come into contact with will be totally safe for me". Even some strong mystics/LoA practitioners Helen Hadsell (winner of 5000 contests) or Ernest Cobb (a.k.a. the Slot Guru, makes a living by winning tons on slots consistently) don't win 100% of the time, but they clearly have influence over their luck to be exceptional compared to regular people.

Now, I might have interpreted this passage wrong, but here's a Biblical example:
>The next day as they were leaving Bethany, Jesus was hungry. Seeing in the distance a fig tree in leaf, he went to find out if it had any fruit. When he reached it, he found nothing but leaves, because it was not the season for figs. Then he said to the tree, “May no one ever eat fruit from you again.” And his disciples heard him say it.

You might as well ask, "Why didn't the tree have a fig on it? Jesus clearly assumed that there would be a fig to eat!"

From my point of view, just goes to show that even among masters, not everything goes your way unless you consciously take control over every aspect of your life. And with how LoA is taught by guys like Neville, you're not really taught to micromanage everything to go perfectly, you just know that even if things do go wrong in the moment, in the end the results will end up in your favor.

Paolucci uses napkins and forks and knives, and jars of water and waveforms, and dolls and horses, as his metaphors because he lacks (or refuses to apply?) any kind of metaphorical background from any other preexisting context. There is ZERO poetry in his work, it is entirely something that he invented himself using common things he saw around him in this modern world. On one hand I can appreciate it because it is truly culturally neutral, on the other hand it makes it almost impossible to comprehend by anyone because we are all so used to using existing poetic and metaphorical shorthands to understand these things already. To read Paolucci you need to learn a new language entirely just to understand something that has probably been more aptly explained or translated into your own language already. Paolucci covers nothing that Goddard hasn't covered in fewer and easier words, namely because Goddard is not opposed to appropriating God and Christian cosmology which already contains an encoded wisdom and using that as the basis of New Thought, instead of napkins and forks and waves and lines and shit like Paolucci.

The letting go part naturally occurs when you get the feeling that the desire has been granted — a feeling of fulfillment. You're not obligated to let go, it's just natural.

The conscious protects the subconscious like a man protects his woman. A man does not share everything with his woman, and thus the conscious does not share everything with the subconscious. When the desire is fulfilled, the subconscious gets impregnated and will give birth to the manifestation.

You'll reach a certain level of mastery when all you do is assume the desire is granted and yours, and it is done. I say "mastery" but you do so every day, like those little (often disregarded) assumptions that everyone makes about anything.
That when you KNOW imaginal acts become facts, you simply assume and let it be.

In fact, the highest technique you hope to achieve is to have no technique. To have such mastery over Self that all you need to do is simply assume, and it is done.
The greatest commandments are the most simple. Like God saying "Let there be light, and there was light". (Genesis 1:3)

I don't have a mounted a dragon, changed my sex or similar story, but is still interesting indeed.
I've had contact with LoA before really knowing about LoA. I was naturally inclined to daydream since I was a child, my father was considered a "witcher" for various members of my family and the few times I had the opportunity to talk with him, he was very a very /x/ man with me, he always gave me lots of books as gifts and the last one was his "collection" of ufo/paranormal magazines. He was kinda focused in me thinking outside the box, telling me to try to burn out lightbulbs with my mind and shit like that. That made me read a lot and became a bookworm.
That made me read all the fucking books in a bookshelf a relative had. In that big bookshelf I found Robert B. Stone book The Magic of Psychotronic Power. I did exercises in the book, used it, got some returns but as I was just a teenager, some things "didn't happened" just because I was an autistic pussy and didn't took them.
One of the techniques in the book tell you to get paper cards and to write something you want to have, need, something you want to happen or you want to become in one card, one thing per card. Then you order them in priority order and imagine getting them, giving more time to the higher priority ones and removing "seconds" of imagining time per card until you finished them all. If you had 30 cards, you would imagine the first one for 40 secs, the next one for 39 and so on until the last one imagined just for 10 seconds. You also had to remove cards every time the thing in the card happened.
I made a deck of cards and did that for a time, when I was bored or in the nights before bed. I removed like 2-3 cards, nothing incredible at the time, being a stupid teenager, but I stopped, don't remember why.
The thing is, I found the cards some years ago and most of the things in them happened and they are still happening. My life was almost in that deck of cards and is crazy.

How do I get rid of self defeating thoughts?

posts.name: WERDS4
posts.com:
>>33948062
The answer is simple, the path is slightly more difficult. I'll give you a structure of principles and then possibly an example.

First thing, understand that the more you practice something, the stronger it gets. It's like weight training. The more you do it the better you get at it. If you keep up with the self defeating thoughts you will get good at that.

To remove anything we dislike, you need to change a few environmental things to support you. Think of it as building a new habit or thought pattern of no self defeating thoughts.

once you practice an engrain that into your system then the self defeating thoughts will wither like an unused muscle.

A couple ways is change 1 aspect of your routine and implement a new habit with it. For example eat a different breakfast than usual, or at a different time, and carry a pocket journal with you.

Every time you have a self defeating thought notice it and jot down that you had one in the journal with the date and time.

When you start to notice them, then you can start to see patterns and then change those patterns. if anything triggers them. then remove the triggers. If they pop up spontaneously change what you are doing and think of something positive about yourself (your alive and breathing for example)

meditation helps to notice these things that we simply do. so consider that.

TL;DR
change one routine you have, carry an implement you don't typically like a pocket journal. notice when you have those thoughts and change them to a positive thought. meditate .

If you want visualizations specifically, pick an object, start simple, look at the object all over for a bit then and place it in front of you. Then close your eyes and imagine the same object. Rotate it in your mind's eye (imagination). Eventually over time add more detail (shading, depth background, time of day etc)
OR
start with a simple shape like a blue circle and hold that image. Then overtime add more. Make it a sphere and rotate it. or a cylinder shape and rotate it. Make it translucent and add another object inside it like a pyramid. Rotate them together, rotate them independently and so on.

If you want a simple daily practice instead (not visual) sit on a chair knees lower than hips. Hands on your knees (keep your knees and legs together for the whole practice) breath into your belly through your nose for a count of 6 seconds and exhale for a count of 6 seconds.

Most of us could, we can still get back it just takes time to clear all the gunk that is in the way.
It sounds boring but the foundational work is key.
Sit quietly on a chair, knees below your hips, hands on your knees and breathing in and out the nose. inhale 6 seconds, exhale 6 seconds. Do this everyday. I say aim for 30 mins to 60 mins.
This will start clearing out the gunk. It's like clogged piping. we only get a trickle. If you want to have the full water pressure, you need to remove all the sticky gunk and that takes some time. This is the starting place.
If you want faster results, consider a moving meditation since that is much more powerful (but harder).

posts.com:
As a user of psychedelics I am pretty confident you can take your state of mind to very similar or even the same places by other means such as dedicated and intense meditation techniques.
It's just much more reliable, easier, faster and more chaotic to get to that mental state when it's done with psychedelic substances.

I have no proof, I haven't even really gotten so deep in regards to meditation to be able to reach that level myself and I'm kind of a moron, but from what little I've experienced and from the words of others I'm pretty confident that meditation when taken seriously can take you into very peculiar states of minds that seems very similar to where psychedelics can take you.

To why there is so much pushing for this? Well for one it fits with the "quick-fix" mentality of modern society, it takes too much effort and time to reliably reach those places via other means, but it sure as hell is easy to ingest some substance and experience wonderful (or terrifying) things.

The other is that governments have deliberately suppressed scientific research on these substances for decades and now that it's less taboo and has become more legal to do research on, it seems like there is a lot of knowledge to get from these substances.

Lastly it's also undeniable that these substances has helped people, sometimes with problems that they've fought hard with for years with no prevail. I've taken lots of different drugs and I can honestly say that psychedelics are the ONLY types of drugs that has ever had a net positive in my life. Others have either been more or less destructive socially, economically, with regards to personal development or just totally (heroin lol). Even with drugs that has had no real impact in my life, drugs I've taken once or twice just to experiment has arguably had a negative effect as it automatically paints me in a certain light that's not necessarily seen as positive by society.

Just my two cents

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33948214
It sounds radically different at the moment, but a strange approximation is taking place.
As the common dialect of Brazil is becoming more and more broken and slave-like, intellectual and high class brazilians are slowly reverting to european pronunciation.
On the other hand, with portuguese children becoming more and more tablet bound and the mass of portuguese language content on the internet being of brazilian origin, many of their terms, expressions and pronunciations are being imported.

I predict that the portuguese language will be almost completely uniform by 2100 or so, only with very marked distinctions between social classes.

Replying to the thread: in language lies the essence of a nation's spirit. By learning a language, you find the keys to comprehending the nation that gave birth it. Once you speak it fluently you start to partake in that spirit, although of course you will never "have it" as a native speaker does, no matter how diligently you study.

posts.sub: Guide to the Bots of Dead Internet
posts.com:
The 3 main types of bots are:


>Explicit/Known Bots) Bots that expose themselves as bots 100% or are touted as bots. It is confirmed without a doubt that they are bots.

>Obvious Bots) Bots that are not 100% confirmed to be a bot, but by their actions and/or appearance, one can easily deduce it as one. They tend to be used for scams,but this is not always the case.

>Cryptobots) Literally meaning 'hidden bot', these bots act pretty much how one would expect an actual user to and are not off, but usually get exposed either by triggering them or by them randomly acting aggressive/off/bizarre. They are not to be confused with cryptocurencybots, though there are probably cryptocurrency cryptobots.

Some species of bots are:

>Attackbots) Bots that are hostile/rude/gaslighty, sometimes mildly, but many times comically so, most Cryptobots turn out to be this kind. They usually attack you for triggering their program, but sometimes will attack unprovoked, usually in waves with other Attackbots. A subspecies of these bots are called Hit-and-run bots, bots that tend to attack from nowhere and never interact with you beyond that.

>Susbots/Satanic Bots/Edgy Bots) Bots that usually do not attack unless provoked or called but have very vile names and/or include a 666 in their name. May or may not act perverted/sick. A synchbot is a subspecies of Susbot that is less vile, but still sus, as they tend to have names that are personal/relevant to you, or that are relevant to the topic at hand or the users behavior.

Brobots)Bot that are kind to users and will tend to help them out, at least a bit. Usually still give off an off artificial vibe,but a non-hostile or not gross one.

Fillerbots)Bots that are there just to seem like real users, they are varied, but in general do not exhibit any of the other traits.

•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.

Fark... I'm a tard..
Please take my words here >>33948641 within the right context; I did a shit job at clarifying it...

(1) past (2) present/action (3) outcome..

One must still NOT break the rules of what the card is related to...
One can say that something was (1) but you (2) to make it (3)....
You can NOT state that something was (3) but you (2) to make it (1)....

I do not give many readings, but my head was spinning at that time remembering the difficulty of constructing a coherent sentence describing it was (1) but you (2) unto making it (3)...
I've found that when constructing a sentence for the reading it is sometimes easier to mention them out of sequence... like explaining it as (3) blah blah blah (2) blah blah blah (1).....
or even (3) blah blah blah (1) blah blah blah (2)....

BUT in all cases I must express it as a thing that was (1) but you did (2) towards making it (3)..
I would be getting it wrong if I stated it was something (3) and you did (2) to turn it into (1)... that would be wrong.. also, wrong if I state it was previously (2) but you did (3) to turn into (1)... and wrong if I stated it was previously (2) but you did (1) to turn into (3).....

What I was trying to express here >>33948641 was....
>I do not give many readings, but my head was spinning at that time remembering the difficulty of constructing a coherent sentence describing it was (1) but you (2) unto making it (3)...
>I've found that when constructing a sentence for the reading it is sometimes easier to mention them out of sequence... like explaining it as (3) blah blah blah (2) blah blah blah (1).....
>or even (3) blah blah blah (1) blah blah blah (2)....
The overall of the reading must still always indicate that (1) was the past of it, so you (2) in order to make it into (3)...

I have a few ways to proof a cards exact meaning in
*my bad

I can indeed work out the specific meaning of what a specific cards mean in a specific position.. but each card takes time.. so progress is slow..

I've come to grumpily realize that until I carry out the testing to see exactly what that specific card means in that specific location for that specific spread/layout... all my pre-conceptions about it is would either be completely wrong, not so far off, or spot on accurate...
So I resign myself to never speculate its meaning because there is as much a chance I'm completely wrong as there is the chance I'm spot on correct...

The situation I'm in is that.......
I've fully mapped out the meanings of all the Major Arcana cards for all positions within the 3-card spread... but have hardly even touched the minor arcana meanings for that 3-card spread...

I've mapped out practically none of the position dependent meanings of the Major Arcana for the 4-card-spread, but have mapped out more than half of the position dependent meanings for the minor arcana for the 4-card-spread...

My problem is that even though I can work out an unknown value for one position within a particular spread for one particular card within only a few hours... attempting to do the entire tarot deck for every position of a specific spread/layout takes a very longgggggggggggg time...

posts.name: Poncho
posts.com:
>>33949375
-Every card has multiple definitions
-Card positions change the meanings
-When you compare the question to the card definitions and the position meanings, the card definitions become clear to just one maybe two definitions
-now that you have specific card definitions and what they mean in the card positions compared to the question, you can read it like a story
-this is where intuition or "feeling" comes in. How do all of the cards interact? What's their story? What happens if you read each card one at a time? Left to right? Right to left? All at once? Try and picture a movie or a short story. Fill out the story according to the question. It takes practice to make the story as long it as short as you want it. If you're new, write short stories. Once you get better make them longer. What helped me making them more detailed or longer is using more cards in position meanings. What also helped is asking querants to give me more details of the question. You can try some spreads here but be warned some you wont find easy to use>>33948081
ABOVE ALL: PRACTICE HERE
dont be afraid of getting it wrong. You're going to get it wrong. I got three reads wrong in a row Thursday night. Just do it.
